descriptionSet.description: Caucasian (American?) couple dressed in evening suits/dress, looking at each other while he lights her cigarette. She seems to sit, he stands behind her. The background is red.

inscription.text: "Yes, it's a WILLS's GOLD FLAKE" It's a CLEAN SMOKE

Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: "Yes, it's a WILLS's GOLD FLAKE" It's a CLEAN SMOKE
text-en: [indecipherable signature at the lower right]
description-en: Caucasian (American?) couple dressed in evening suits/dress, looking at each other while he lights her cigarette. She seems to sit, he stands behind her. The background is red.
explanatory comments/crosstagging: Blonde hair as well as red hair is a distinctive visual marker on advertising images for being Western and therefore an exclusive marker for whiteness. (la)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: According to Erving Goffman in his study "Gender Advertisements" the position of the man and the woman on the image points to the fact that he has a higher status. It is very common to portray men 1) taller than women, 2) while helping the woman in some kind. (la)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Richard Dyer explains in his book "white" that gender portrayals in most still and moving images are unconsciously informed by Christian iconography. In Christianity women were seen as the purer sex, whereas men have a dark inner core that they have to overcome during their lifetime. On images this is mirrored in the fact that females are often lighter than men. Not only in skin colour, but also in the colour of their dress. (la)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: In the first half of the 20th century far less women smoked cigarettes. Therefore many tobacco ads deliberately targeted women with an advertising rhetoric targeted at convincing females that smoking cigarettes gave them elegance and style. See the project of Tim Coyle: http://otal.umd.edu/~vg/amst205.S97/vj05/cigad.html, last accessed 2011-08-21. (la)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: In the Indian context cigarette advertising during almost the entire 20th century featured distinctively Western woman as it was considered to be indecent for Indian woman to smoke in public. Depicting an Indian woman on an ad for cigarettes would most likely have had a negative effect. See also the article on early Indian advertising by Javeer Masood on Tasveerghar. (la)
related hyperlinks: http://otal.umd.edu/~vg/amst205.S97/vj05/cigad.html, last accessed 2011-08-21, Tom Coyle's "Cigarettes" Project #5 (la)
